titleStmt.title: HORACE, PART OF BOOK I. SAT. VI.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: IF noisy Tom 1Sir Thomas Prendergast. IRISH ED. should in the senate prate,
“That he would answer both for church and state;
“And, further to demonstrate his affection,
“Would take the kingdom into his protection:”
All mortals must be curious to inquire,
Who could this coxcomb be, and who his sire?

“What! thou, the spawn of him 2The father of Sir Thomas P────, who engaged in a plot to murder king William III; but, to avoid being hanged, turned informer against his associates, for which he was rewarded with a good estate, and made a baronet. Ibid. who sham'd our isle,
“That traitor, assassin, informer vile!
“Though by the female side 3Cadogan's family. IRISH ED. you proudly bring,
“To mend your breed, the murderer of a king:
“What was thy grandsire 4A poor thieving cottager under Mr. Moore, condemned at Clonmell assizes to be hanged for stealing cows. Ibid. but a mountaineer,
“Who held a cabbin for ten groats a year;
“Whose master Moore 5The grandfather of Guy Moore, esq; who procured him a pardon. Ibid.` preserv'd him from the halter,
“For stealing cows; nor could he read the Psalter!
“Durst thou, ungrateful, from the senate chace

“Thy founder's grandson 6Guy Moore was fairly elected member of parliament for Clonme, but Sir Thomas, depending upon his interest with a certain party then prevailing, and since known by the title of Parson-hunters, petitioned the house against him; out of which he was turned upon pretence of bribery, which the paying of his lawful debts was then voted to be. Ibid., and usurp his place?
“Just heaven! to see the dunghill bastard brood
“Survive in thee, and make the proverb good7“Save a thief from the gallows, and he will cut your throat.” Ibid.!
“Then vote a worthy citizen 8Mr. George Faulkner. See the verses in the following page. N. to jail,
“In spite of justice, and refuse his bail!”825-79L2
